awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social Movements Impacts on Urban Waste Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposed study will investigate the social movements that are driving one major US city to address food recovery and composting initiatives. The study will identify what conditions are facilitating competing and diverse actors and strategies to work together in order to transform a large city waste system. The findings will be of interest to community organizers, policy makers, city urban designers and planners who are managing, updating and maintaining urban waste systems.
 
This research will ask what happens to a huge, obdurate sociotechnical system when it is challenged by numerous alternative solutions.  The research will examine how top-down and bottom-up designs are coordinated through the deployment of future projections by people developing alternative food waste systems.  The study will use a mixed-methods, multi-sited design to understand how actors building alternative food waste systems in New York City imagine and coordinate projected futures as they create new infrastructures. Data collection will include: 1) participant observation of design, building and maintenance of alternative food waste infrastructures; 2) participant observation at planning and policy events; 3) semi-structured interviews with organizers, volunteers, and users of systems; and 4) daily use of, and interactions with, emerging food infrastructures. This study will demonstrate how informal urbanism can create decentralized solutions to the complex problem of waste. Insights about the effectiveness and pitfalls of this approach to sociotechnical transformation will help to inform policy makers and designers seeking effective ways to weave together centralized and situated approaches to green infrastructure. Findings will be reported in both scholarly and popular venues and shared with food recovery and composing practitioners.

por.por_cntn:
This study examined the organics recycling program being rolled out by the Department of Sanitation of New York City (DSNY), the largest municipal composting program in the country. Data was collected on the transition to composting, in order to understand the contributions of small, volunteer-run local compost projects to the transformation of the waste infrastructure and waste culture of the city. Two approaches to organics recycling are currently active in New York. Curbside organics collection is similar to existing recycling programs, producing compost that can be sold to farmers and landscapers. The other model, neighborhood composting, keeps food scraps local, encouraging people get to know their waste and supporting community gardens.

This study revealed three important methods by which smaller, local compost systems were exerting influence on the formal operation of compost in New York City. First, they helped to train people to compost and to think about compost, creating a new kind of public that is more amenable to transitions in waste infrastructure. Second, in some cases they have been incorporated into the city’s infrastructure, which offers the projects stability as they work to build local composting systems. Third, they conduct public experiments with waste, inviting people in neighborhoods to try to understand their role in a resource system, and to develop new visions of the sustainable city that can work for everyone in a neighborhood.

These results are important for community composters and for municipalities trying to transition to compost. They demonstrate that community compost plays an important role in the growth of citywide compost systems and in the cultural changes necessary to create a composting city. Compost is becoming an increasingly important strategy in waste management; at most recent count, 198 U.S. cities have municipal food waste composting programs, and 2.74 million households (about 2% of U.S. households) are serviced by a municipal compost program. Understanding the value of neighborhood-scale composting will increase the success of these programs.

These results also have important implications for science and technology studies because they demonstrate that innovation can involve an ongoing process of public input. In addition, this study demonstrates patterns by which informal systems can exert an influence on the more formal realms of city planning.
